intro: Chamaesyce serpillifolia subsp. hirtula, commonly known as hairy sandspurry, is a low-growing perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal or arid environments. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs, giving it a textured appearance. Its flowers are usually yellow, with five petals, and appear in clusters during the spring. It is a member of the family Portulacaceae, known for its succulent-like characteristics and ability to tolerate harsh conditions.
